1. Eczema 1677.name: Eczema
1. Eczema 1677.description: Eczema is a condition that causes itchy, inflamed, and cracked skin. It's a chronic inflammatory skin condition that can develop at any age. The exact cause is unknown but involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
symptoms: Small raised bumps that may leak fluid when scratched

2. Melanoma 15.75k.name: Melanoma
2. Melanoma 15.75k.description: Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer. It develops from melanocytes (pigment-producing cells) and can spread to other parts of the body if not treated early. It's often caused by intense, intermittent sun exposure and severe sunburns.
symptoms: Multiple colors in one mole (brown, black, tan, red)
treatment: Lymph node removal if spread occurs
prevention: Get annual skin checks from dermatologist

3. Atopic Dermatitis - 1.25k.name: Atopic Dermatitis
3. Atopic Dermatitis - 1.25k.description: Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by intense itching and sensitive skin. Also known as eczema, it's more common in children but can develop at any age. It often runs in families with allergies or asthma.
symptoms: Small, raised bumps that may leak fluid

4. Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) 3323.name: Basal Cell Carcinoma
4. Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) 3323.description: Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, arising from basal cells in the epidermis. It grows slowly and rarely spreads to other parts of the body, but should be treated promptly to prevent scarring.
symptoms: Pearly or waxy bump on skin
Bleeding or oozing sore that doesn't heal
Lesion with rolled edges and central indentation
prevention: Report any new or changing skin lesions

5. Melanocytic Nevi (NV) - 7970.name: Melanocytic Nevi
5. Melanocytic Nevi (NV) - 7970.description: Melanocytic nevi are common benign skin growths (moles) that arise from melanocytes. Most people have several to dozens of nevi. While usually harmless, they should be monitored for changes as some can rarely transform into melanoma.

6. Benign Keratosis-like Lesions (BKL) 2.name: Benign Keratosis-like Lesions
6. Benign Keratosis-like Lesions (BKL) 2.description: Benign keratosis-like lesions are common, noncancerous skin growths that typically appear as brown, black, or tan wartlike spots on the skin. They're harmless but may be removed for cosmetic reasons.

7. Psoriasis pictures Lichen Planus and.name: Psoriasis and Lichen Planus
7. Psoriasis pictures Lichen Planus and.description: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory skin condition characterized by thick, scaly, red patches. Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition affecting skin and mucous membranes. Both are chronic but manageable.

8. Seborrheic Keratoses and other Benign.name: Seborrheic Keratosis
8. Seborrheic Keratoses and other Benign.description: Seborrheic keratosis is a common, benign skin growth that typically appears as a brown, black, or tan wartlike spot. More common with age, these growths are harmless but can be removed if irritated or for cosmetic reasons.
symptoms: May itch or become irritated if rubbed

9. Tinea Ringworm Candidiasis and other.name: Fungal Infections (Tinea, Ringworm, Candidiasis)
9. Tinea Ringworm Candidiasis and other.description: Fungal skin infections are caused by dermatophytes or yeasts. Common types include tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea corporis (ringworm), and candidiasis. These are contagious and thrive in warm, moist environments.
symptoms: Circular rash with raised red edges
prevention: Use antifungal powder in high-risk areas
Don't share towels or personal items
Avoid direct contact with infected persons

10. Warts Molluscum and other Viral Infe.name: Warts, Molluscum, and Viral Infections
10. Warts Molluscum and other Viral Infe.description: Viral skin infections include common warts, genital warts, molluscum contagiosum, and other viral skin conditions. These are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and molluscipoxvirus. Most are contagious and can spread through direct contact.
symptoms: May have dark specks in center (warts)
